page.title: 03The Devil's Hole (2)
page.content: Nicholas Arthur, the man who saved the crew paid a sculptor (John Gifford of St.Peter) to add arms, a trident, horns, and a tail to the figurehead, so the devil was created and a new name was given to the{'Creux de Vis':} The Devil's Hole. The devil remained on show for one hundred years until, in July 1951, some jokers came and took the effigy and placed it outside the offices of 'The Evening Post' (the local newspaper). In 1957 it was again taken and burned to ashes in the name of the Ku-Klux-Klan. A figure in fibre-glass was made and remains to this day. A visit to the view point above the cave is a favourite tourist attraction.
